seg.input:
Leoni suo gratiam et pacem a domino.
Ita zelo dei, frater mi, adversus sanguinarium Fabrum suique similes lugurthas excandeo, ut ipse mihi temperare non potuerim, quin haec pauca moneremus, nempe ut legas Ambrosii 2. lib. offitiorum cap. 28 et Lactantium in 6, «De vero cultu» cap. 25; sic, ut ex ipsis patribus Thrasonis profligetur impietas, qua impulsus pauperibus detrahit, harpigiis vero papisticis convehit et insontes sacrilegii accusat, scilicet quod ecclesiam dei, hoc est larvas, ficulneos, lamias, lemures et lares spoliaverint. Etsi non ignorem fortiorem esse scripturae authoritatem, quae stat a partibus nostris, attamen ardor hic nescio quis compulit, ut Minervam sus monerem.
Vale. Salutabis mihi Zuinglium.
Cappellae, 11. maii in 1526.
seg.output:
May the Lord grant you peace and grace.
So great is my zeal for God, my brother, and my hatred for the bloody Faber and his like, that I could not restrain myself from writing these few words to you, to read the second book of Ambrose’s “On Duties”, chapter 28, and Lactantius’ “On True Worship”, chapter 25; so that the impiety of Thrasonis may be brought down from the Fathers themselves, whereby, being driven by passion, he takes away from the poor, and carries away with Papist harpies and accuses the innocent of sacrilege, for having, as it were, plundered the temple of God, that is, the images, the ficulneos, the lamia, the lemures and the lares. Though I am aware of a stronger authority of the scriptures, which are on our side, yet an unknown ardor forced me to admonish Minerva.
Farewell. Greet Zwingli for me.
Cappelle, 11th May 1526.
